benchPressBenchmarking.title: Bench Press Strength Standards
benchPressBenchmarking.description: Strength benchmarks for bench press based on body weight ratio (1RM/Body Weight in pounds)

instructions.title: How to Perform the Bench Press
steps: Lie flat on the bench with your eyes directly under the barbell
Plant your feet firmly on the floor, maintaining contact throughout the movement
Grip the barbell slightly wider than shoulder-width apart
Unrack the bar and position it directly above your chest with arms fully extended
Lower the bar in a controlled manner to your mid-chest, keeping elbows at approximately 45-degree angle
Pause briefly when the bar touches your chest
Press the bar back up explosively to the starting position, fully extending your arms
Maintain shoulder blade retraction and keep your upper back tight throughout
safetyTips: Always use a spotter when attempting heavy weights
Warm up thoroughly before attempting your one-rep max
Keep your wrists straight and aligned with your forearms
Avoid bouncing the bar off your chest
Breathe out during the pressing phase and in during the lowering phase

oneRepMax.title: One Rep Max (1RM) Calculation
oneRepMax.description: Your 1RM is the maximum weight you can lift for one complete repetition with proper form

formulas.name: Epley Formula
formulas.description: Most commonly used formula for estimating 1RM

formulas.name: Brzycki Formula
formulas.description: Alternative formula, often more accurate for higher rep ranges

formulas.name: Direct Testing
formulas.description: Most accurate but requires proper warm-up and safety precautions

oneRepMax.note: For safety and accuracy, it's recommended to test 1RM using 3-5 rep max and applying the formula rather than attempting a true 1RM

measurement.title: How to Measure Your Bench Press Strength

steps.description: Determine your body weight in pounds
Calculate or test your one-rep max (1RM) using proper form
Divide your 1RM by your body weight to get your ratio
Compare your ratio to the standards table based on your age and gender

example.scenario: A 30-year-old male weighing 180 pounds with a 1RM of 200 pounds
example.rating: Good (falls within 1.01-1.07 range for 30-39 age group)

measurement.units: All measurements are in pounds. Body weight and 1RM should both be measured in the same unit.

progressionTips: Test your 1RM every 8-12 weeks to track progress
Focus on progressive overload by gradually increasing weight or reps
Maintain proper form over lifting heavier weights
Include accessory exercises like dumbbell press, push-ups, and tricep work
Ensure adequate rest (48-72 hours) between heavy bench press sessions

legPressBenchmarking.title: Leg Press Strength Standards
legPressBenchmarking.description: Strength benchmarks for leg press (seated or lying) based on body weight ratio (1RM/Body Weight in pounds)

instructions.title: How to Perform the Leg Press

steps: Sit in the leg press machine with your back flat against the padded support
Place your feet on the platform at shoulder-width apart, toes pointed slightly outward
Position your feet in the middle to upper portion of the platform
Release the safety bars and extend your legs without locking your knees
Lower the weight in a controlled manner by bending your knees toward your chest
Stop when your knees reach approximately 90 degrees or your thighs are parallel to the platform
Push through your heels to extend your legs back to the starting position
Keep your lower back pressed against the pad throughout the movement
Lie back on the leg press machine with your back and head resting against the padded support
Place your feet on the footplate at shoulder-width apart, centered on the platform
Grip the handles on the sides for stability
Release the safety handles and hold the platform with slightly bent knees
Lower the platform by bending your knees in a controlled manner
Continue until your knees are at approximately 90 degrees
Press through your heels and midfoot to push the platform back up
Avoid locking your knees at the top of the movement

safetyTips: Never lock your knees at full extension
Keep your lower back flat against the pad to avoid injury
Don't let your knees cave inward during the movement
Avoid lowering the weight too far (past 90 degrees) if you have knee issues
Always engage the safety stops before releasing the weight
Breathe out during the pressing phase and in during the lowering phase
Start with lighter weights to master proper form

oneRepMax.title: One Rep Max (1RM) Calculation for Leg Press
oneRepMax.description: Your 1RM is the maximum weight you can press for one complete repetition with proper form

formulas.name: Epley Formula
formulas.description: Most commonly used formula for estimating 1RM

formulas.name: Brzycki Formula
formulas.description: Alternative formula, particularly useful for leg press calculations

formulas.name: Lombardi Formula
formulas.description: Another reliable option for lower body exercises

formulas.name: Direct Testing
formulas.description: Most accurate but requires thorough warm-up and spotter assistance

oneRepMax.note: For leg press, it's recommended to test using a 5-8 rep max and calculate 1RM using a formula, as direct 1RM testing can be risky for the knees and lower back

measurement.title: How to Measure Your Leg Press Strength

steps.description: Determine your body weight in pounds
Perform a proper warm-up with progressive weight increases
Calculate your one-rep max (1RM) using a 5-8 rep test and formula
Divide your 1RM by your body weight to get your strength ratio
Compare your ratio to the standards table based on your age and gender

example.scenario: A 35-year-old female weighing 140 pounds who can leg press 300 pounds for 5 reps
example.rating: Excellent (>1.42 for 30-39 age group, she scores 2.5)

measurement.units: All measurements are in pounds. Body weight and 1RM should both be measured in the same unit.
measurement.machineNote: Results may vary between seated and lying leg press machines. For consistency, always use the same machine type when tracking progress.

progressionTips: Test your 1RM every 8-12 weeks to monitor improvements
Focus on full range of motion rather than just adding weight
Include unilateral exercises like single-leg press to address imbalances
Vary foot placement (high, low, wide, narrow) to target different muscle groups
Incorporate complementary exercises like squats, lunges, and deadlifts
Allow 48-72 hours of rest between heavy leg press sessions
Maintain proper form even when fatigued to prevent knee and back injuries
Track both weight and reps to monitor overall volume progression

pushUpBenchmarking.title: Push-Up Strength Standards
pushUpBenchmarking.description: Push-up endurance benchmarks by percentile ranking based on age and gender (number of consecutive push-ups)

instructions.title: How to Perform a Proper Push-Up

steps: Start in a plank position with hands placed slightly wider than shoulder-width apart
Position your hands directly under your shoulders with fingers pointing forward
Extend your legs straight back with feet hip-width apart or together
Engage your core and keep your body in a straight line from head to heels
Lower your body by bending your elbows until your chest nearly touches the floor
Keep your elbows at approximately 45 degrees from your body (not flared out)
Push through your palms to extend your arms and return to the starting position
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement - avoid sagging hips or raised buttocks
Complete the full range of motion for each repetition to count

modifiedPushUp.title: Modified Push-Up (Knee Push-Up)
steps: Start in a plank position but with knees on the ground
Place hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart
Cross your ankles and keep them elevated slightly off the ground
Maintain a straight line from knees to head
Lower your chest toward the floor by bending your elbows
Push back up to the starting position
Keep core engaged throughout the movement
modifiedPushUp.note: Modified push-ups are ideal for beginners building strength or when testing endurance

testingProtocol.title: Push-Up Test Protocol
steps: Warm up with 5-10 minutes of light cardio and dynamic stretching
Perform 1-2 sets of 5-10 easy push-ups as specific warm-up
Rest for 2-3 minutes before beginning the test
Assume the standard push-up position
Begin on command and perform as many consecutive push-ups as possible
Maintain proper form throughout - improper form repetitions do not count
Continue until you cannot complete another full repetition with proper form
Record the total number of properly performed push-ups
formRequirements: Body must remain straight throughout the movement
Chest must come within 3-4 inches of the floor
Arms must fully extend at the top
No resting except in the up position
Continuous motion - excessive pausing between reps ends the test

safetyTips: Stop immediately if you experience shoulder, elbow, or wrist pain
Keep your head in a neutral position - don't look up or let it drop
Breathe regularly - inhale on the way down, exhale on the way up
If proper form cannot be maintained, stop the test
Allow at least 48 hours of rest before retesting
Consult a healthcare provider if you have any existing upper body injuries

measurement.title: How to Measure Your Push-Up Strength

steps.description: Warm up thoroughly with light cardio and dynamic stretching
Perform the push-up test following the standard protocol
Count only push-ups performed with proper form
Compare your total count to the standards table based on your age and gender

example.scenario: A 35-year-old male who completes 28 consecutive push-ups
example.rating: Above Average (falls at approximately 80th percentile for 30-39 age group)
example.interpretation: This individual performs better than approximately 80% of men in his age group

percentileExplanation.70th-80th: Above Average - Better than most people

progressionTips: Test your maximum push-ups every 4-6 weeks to track progress
Practice push-ups 3-4 times per week with at least one rest day between sessions
Use progressive overload: increase reps, decrease rest time, or add variations
Include different push-up variations to target muscles differently
Strengthen supporting muscles with planks, shoulder presses, and tricep exercises
Focus on eccentric training (slow lowering phase) to build strength
Ensure adequate protein intake and recovery for muscle growth
If you can do 20+ push-ups easily, try advanced variations or weighted push-ups

easier.name: Wall Push-Ups
easier.description: Stand facing a wall, place hands on wall at shoulder height, perform push-up against wall

easier.name: Incline Push-Ups
easier.description: Place hands on an elevated surface (bench, table) to reduce resistance

easier.name: Knee Push-Ups
easier.description: Perform push-ups with knees on the ground

standard.name: Standard Push-Up
standard.description: Traditional push-up with hands shoulder-width apart

standard.name: Wide-Grip Push-Up
standard.description: Hands placed wider than shoulders to emphasize chest

standard.name: Diamond Push-Up
standard.description: Hands close together forming a diamond shape to target triceps

advanced.name: Decline Push-Up
advanced.description: Feet elevated on a platform to increase difficulty

advanced.name: Plyometric Push-Up
advanced.description: Explosive push-up where hands leave the ground

advanced.name: One-Arm Push-Up
advanced.description: Performed with one arm while the other is behind the back

advanced.name: Weighted Push-Up
advanced.description: Perform with a weight plate or weighted vest

benefits: No equipment needed - can be performed anywhere
Functional exercise that mimics daily pushing movements
Builds upper body strength and muscular endurance
Can be easily modified for all fitness levels
Excellent indicator of overall upper body fitness
